skill.name: signup-flow-cro
skill.description: When the user wants to optimize signup, registration, account creation, or trial activation flows. Also use when the user mentions "signup conversions," "registration friction," "signup form optimization," "free trial signup," "reduce signup dropoff," or "account creation flow." For post-signup onboarding, see onboarding-cro. For lead capture forms (not account creation), see form-cro.
skill.summary: Optimize signup, registration, and trial activation flows to reduce friction and increase conversion rates through evidence-based CRO techniques.
skill.author: coreyhaines31

security_audit.summary: All static findings are false positives. The skill contains only marketing guidance text with no executable code. The scanner misinterpreted business terminology (B2B, B2C, algorithm patterns) as security issues. No network, filesystem, or external command access.

content.value_statement: High signup friction causes users to abandon before completing registration. This skill provides systematic guidance to reduce form abandonment, increase completion rates, and improve user activation through proven conversion optimization techniques.
actual_capabilities: Analyze signup flow friction points and recommend specific improvements
Compare single-step vs multi-step form approaches with decision criteria
Optimize individual form fields including email, password, name, and social auth
Create A/B test hypotheses for signup conversion experiments
Implement trust signals and error handling best practices
limitations: Does not provide code implementation or technical integration
Cannot access or analyze live user analytics data
Does not perform actual conversion rate measurements
Focused on signup flows only, not general page optimization

use_cases.title: E-commerce platform signup optimization
use_cases.description: Reduce cart abandonment by simplifying account creation. Implement guest checkout options and social authentication to streamline the registration process.

use_cases.title: SaaS free trial activation
use_cases.description: Increase free trial signups by minimizing required fields and removing barriers. Design progressive commitment patterns that convert visitors to trial users.

use_cases.title: B2B enterprise registration flow
use_cases.description: Balance data collection needs with conversion friction. Implement SSO options and proper field ordering for complex B2B signup requirements.
use_cases.target_user: UX designers at enterprise software companies

prompt_templates.title: Basic signup audit
prompt_templates.prompt: Audit my signup flow. We have [X] steps with [Y] required fields. Current completion rate is [Z%]. What are the top 3 friction points and how do I fix them?
prompt_templates.scenario: User provides basic signup flow details for analysis

prompt_templates.title: Mobile optimization
prompt_templates.prompt: Our mobile signup completion rate is 20% lower than desktop. Review our mobile form and recommend specific mobile-optimization improvements including touch targets, keyboard types, and layout.

prompt_templates.title: Social auth integration
prompt_templates.prompt: Should we add more SSO options to our signup flow? Our audience is [describe audience]. Which providers should we prioritize and how should we position them relative to email signup?
prompt_templates.scenario: User wants to evaluate social authentication options

prompt_templates.title: Experiment design
prompt_templates.prompt: Design an A/B test for our signup button. Current CTA is 'Create Account'. Propose 3 alternative copy variations with rationale, and outline how to measure the winner.
prompt_templates.scenario: User wants to optimize signup CTA through testing

output_examples.input: Our signup form has 8 fields: email, password, first name, last name, company, role, phone, and team size. Completion rate is 45%.
output: **Critical Issue**: Too many required fields. Users drop off after seeing 3-4 fields.
**Recommended Fix**: Reduce to email + password only. Collect other fields during onboarding.
**Priority**: HIGH - Same-day fix by marking fields optional.

output_examples.input: Mobile users are abandoning at the password field. Our password requirements show only after they type.
output: **Issue**: Password requirements hidden until after input creates frustration.
**Impact**: Users don't know requirements before starting, leading to wasted effort.
**Fix**: Show password requirements upfront. Add real-time strength indicator.
**Also**: Ensure password field accepts paste for easy password manager use.

best_practices: Collect only essential data at signup. Move non-critical fields to post-signup onboarding through progressive profiling.
Show value before asking for commitment. Let users experience product benefits before requiring account creation.
Test single-step vs multi-step approaches. Single-step works for simple flows; multi-step works for complex B2B requirements.
anti_patterns: Requiring phone number or company name when not immediately necessary creates unnecessary friction and abandonment.
Using separate email confirmation fields instead of inline validation doubles input effort and increases drop-off.
Disabling paste in password fields prevents password manager use and frustrates security-conscious users.

faq.question: How many fields should a signup form have?
faq.answer: Aim for 3 or fewer required fields. Every additional field reduces conversion by 5-10%. Essential fields are typically email and password only.

faq.question: Should we use single-step or multi-step signup?
faq.answer: Single-step works best for B2C with 3 or fewer fields. Multi-step suits B2B requiring more data. Always show progress indicators for multi-step flows.

faq.question: Which social auth options should we offer?
faq.answer: Google works for most audiences. B2B should add Microsoft. B2C should consider Apple and Facebook. Position SSO above email signup when available.

faq.question: How do we handle password requirements without frustrating users?
faq.answer: Show requirements upfront before they type. Use a strength meter instead of rigid rules. Allow paste. Consider passwordless options like magic links.

faq.question: Should email verification be required at signup?
faq.answer: Delay verification until necessary when possible. Let users explore the product while awaiting verification. Clear re-engagement emails help if verification stalls.

faq.question: How do we measure signup flow performance?
faq.answer: Track form start rate, completion rate, field-level drop-off, time to complete, and error rate by field. Use analytics on each step in multi-step flows.
